attributes.alt: Book cover for Nobody Hugs a Cactus by Carter Goodrich. The cover shows a small cactus with a sad face, sitting on a shelf.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a name game, and introduce vocabulary
Why does nobody want to hug Hank the cactus?
Read for enjoyment, counting out the characters in the story as you read.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to 5) scattered (Cardinality).
Understand and use varied types of words.
Challenge children to count the characters.
Guide children to identify the number of animals that stop by.
Help children recognize that the last number they say is how many.
How do we talk about and manage our feelings?
What book did you choose? Why did you choose that one?
Pretend that you are happy. What is making you happy? What do you do when you are happy?
Grab a group of buttons. How many buttons are there?
Write about someone who came to visit you. How did you spend your time together?
Make a happy poster. What colors will you use? Why?
What letter did you make? How did you make it?
What are you building? How many blocks have you used so far?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Nobody Hugs a Cactus by Carter Goodrich. The cover shows a small cactus with a sad face, sitting on a shelf.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the mind builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about understanding and managing feelings.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to 5) scattered (Cardinality).
Understand and use varied types of words.
Verbally share the meaning of their own writing.
Guide children to share cubes with a partner.
Challenge children to count the number of cubes given. Then have children swap roles.
Have children discuss emotions when sharing.
How do we talk about and manage our feelings?
How does the character in that book show her feelings?
Can you act like you’re surprised? What surprised you?
Make a group of three counters. How can you check that there are three in all?
Have you ever seen a desert? Can you write about one?
Draw a picture that shows someone feeling angry.
Trace the word feelings. What letters do you see?
Why did you use those materials to build that?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Nobody Hugs a Cactus by Carter Goodrich. The cover shows a small cactus with a sad face, sitting on a shelf.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to practice counting, engage children with a physical activity, and introduce vocabulary
Why did Hank change his mind about wanting to live alone?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to 5) scattered (Cardinality).
Understand and use varied types of words.
Guide children to take a set number of Connecting Cubes representing desert plants out of a bag.
Challenge children to count out the number of cubes and make sure they have the correct total.
How do we talk about and manage our feelings?
How do the characters in that book manage their feelings?
How could you pretend to be happy? Sad? Angry?
Can you make two groups of different objects? How many are in each group? How many in all?
Describe how you would take care of a cactus like Hank.
Can you draw an angry face? Why does that face look angry?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of sad?
How did you choose what to build? How did you choose what to make it with?

attributes.alt: A chart with the title If You're Happy and You Know It. Children's faces are next to speech bubbles that say Happy, Sad, Angry, Scared, Surprised, Silly, Excited, and Loved.

elements.text: If You’re Happy and You Know It

attributes.alt: Book cover for Nobody Hugs a Cactus by Carter Goodrich. The cover shows a small cactus with a sad face, sitting on a shelf.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about feelings, engage children with dance, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
If You’re Happy and You Know It
Read interactively and connect to managing emotions and counting.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to 5) scattered (Cardinality).
Understand and use varied types of words.
Count a number of cubes behind a “curtain” and ask children to match that number of cubes on their side of the curtain.
Count cubes on both sides to check for the same number of cubes.
How do we talk about and manage our feelings?
How do you feel about this story?
Pretend to be one of Hank’s friends in the desert. Why did you choose that friend?
Make two patterns and compare them. Which is longer?
Choose an emotion. Write about a time that you felt it.
Draw to show the difference between scared and surprised.
What sound do you hear at the beginning of cactus? Can you draw that letter?
How can you make what you are building bigger?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Nobody Hugs a Cactus by Carter Goodrich. The cover shows a small cactus with a sad face, sitting on a shelf.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to practice identifying numbers and introduce vocabulary
What would you tell Hank to help him manage his feelings?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on emotions.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set when objects are arranged (up to 10) in a line, a rectangular array, in a circle, or (up to 5) scattered (Cardinality).
Understand and use varied types of words.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
How do you manage your feelings?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
How do we talk about and manage our feelings?
What kind of book do you want to read next?
Pretend to be an animal in the desert. What will you be? How will you act?
Use counters to represent groups of friends. How many friends are in each group?
What story can you tell about someone who feels calm?
Can you draw a new friend for a cactus? What will it look like?
Can you count the number of letters in your name?
What did you build? How many blocks did you use?

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Nobody Hugs a Cactus by Carter Goodrich. Copyright © 2019 by Carter Goodrich. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing Division, a division of Simon & Schuster, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
